On tap at Sunset Grill. Served in a tulip glass. A deep dark brew. Frothy light tan head that settles to nothing. Aroma of sweet oak with a little roasty smoke. Flavor is rich and slightly tangy, with an assertive sweetness that is kept well in balance. Very good.

On tap at Always Ron's in Hagerstown, MD.

Clear, deep ruby-brown with a large pale khaki head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of raisins, caramel, prunes and sweet dark fruit. 

Taste of caramel, raisins, prunes, toffee, vanilla and brown sugar. 

Medium/full body and medium carbonation.

Not as complex as some of its Belgian counterparts, but plenty tasty.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Alla Spina with PJ and Pat. Pours a dark brown body with thin off white lacing. Aroma is caramel malt, light vanilla and oak. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of sweet caramel malts upfront with subdued flavors of vanilla, oak, roast, booze and spice in the background.

2013.05.02 - Allagash Odyssey - on tap at Always Ron's.  

Shorter than normal review.  Pours dark with sticky head.  Aroma pretty neutral tony nose. Agree with review below, kind of malty wheat then sweeter on back end.  Less malty sweetness than I would hope and more of a grainy wheat element.  Nothing wrong with this but nothing distinguishing to me.  Coming from a Belgian Strong Ale fan. 

5/4/6/3/13

2013 batch, paid $17.99 locally enjoyed at 60F in a tulip.

A -  Dark brown, amber edges, nice lacing. light head

S - Smells like candy. hints of oak and vanilla with caramel and candied sugar. not a lot of dark fruits.

T -  Pretty sweet at the finish, up front a more maltier wheat taste. I get some sweet candied sugar, not bready or yeasty at all. pretty basic

M - Heavy body, medium carbonation balances it out.

O - This beer is just okay. Glad I didnt cellar it. Its just a mediocre beer for $18.

Dark cider/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, yeast, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of smoky sweet malt, yeast, oak, dark fruit (notably plums & dates), caramel/vanilla, and spice; Nicely balanced and fairly complex; Overall, subtle in flavor - but well made.
Draft at Alla Spina. Pours a deep cloudy brown with some tan head and lace. Notes of roasted malt, figs, some chocolate, oak, raisin. Tasty

on tap at Duckworths (NC) 

Pour is a bit light for the style; but then I see this is partly a dark wheat beer. The clear dark brown/amber body is covered by a bone head that has great retention 

Mouthfeel: near medium body with well-chose, soft carbonation. Very smooth. 

Taste and Aroma: Wheaty, with plenty of alcohol esters and Belgian yeast. Also rather sweet up front. with hints of caramel and brown sugar, but ends mildly bitter.  

O: Low on dark fruit for style, this Belgian ale was disappointing but should appeal more to folks who like wild yeast and wheat in their beers more than I do.

Draft at craft ale house. Pours clear brown with a small off white head. The aroma Is light chocolate, light roast. The taste has a little roasted chocolate, some toffee. For the abv, a little watery. Not bad.

Draft @ Oakquinox 2013. Mahogany pour with an off-white head. Some bread and toffee malt aroma. Some dark fruit, spice, and wood. Not terribly sweet and a bit herbal. The flavor is very toasty and heavy on the oak. Mild to moderate malt sweetness of toffee and toasted bread. Spice and herb flavors, yeast, dark fruit, and a hint of smoke.
Dark amber; thick and chewy; malty sweet some smokyness;  finishes sweet with some hoppy bitters

750 ml bottle

Thanks to tastybeer for sharing this. Its been while since I tried something new from Allagash. This was a passable release. Ill continue to try a few new things but it might be a while yet before I revisit this East Coast brewery.

Aroma / Appearance - The carbonated base looks like melted chocolate which has been watered down to keep it from thickening up. An ivory head looks like frosty icing. Smoky bacon, chestnuts, and peat give this a malty profile. If there are any hops they are well masked.

Flavor / Palate - Smoky chocolate is the first impression of a mildly complex beer. It lingers for a while before fading to nothing. More presence would help this greatly. As it stands I kept looking for more and not finding it. Also if there was any barrel aging it too is hidden.

Bottle, ruby/brown pour, light tan head. Good retention/some lace. Aroma of caramel, marshmallow, chocolate, wheat malt. Taste is sweet, light smoke, marshmallow, toffee. Palate is soft, a bit sticky, sweet finish.

Slight foam lacing in my glass. The scent is nice. I smell carmel malts, spices, grains, and oak. I taste sugar, yeast, malts, oaky wood, dark fruit, and wheat. There is a mild dryness in the finish that fades quickly. The palate is mildly hit. Overall this a fine beverage.

Big Thanks to Adam!!! From notes - sample pour of deep amber/brown with full head of off white.  Nose is caramel, toffee, raisins, figs, burnt sugar, and slight sour milk.. Flavor comes in three parts... Sharp sweetness to start, smooth malt and a lingering sugar toffee, smooth caramel, and burnt sugar.  Medium body with smooth lacing.
2009 bottle. Woodiness dominates the nose to the point where the beer is almost a little smoky.  Lots of vanilla, sweet malt, oakiness. Interesting beer. Tasty, but Im glad I split a bottle.
Bottle and Draught.  One of my favorite Allagash special brews.  Really woody and well spiced.

Bottle shared from Jcr, thanks! Pours deep red or brown. Nose is complex fruitiness, oak, vanilla, rich malt sweetness, toffee and nut. Light bitterness and somewhat sweet. Full rich mouthfeel. Warm. Nice fruity, rich and satisfying brew.

December 2011, bottling, aged approx 1 year.  Very good subtle belgian.  Pours translucent brown, white head, significant lacing.  Aroma is faint oak, sweet, malt.  Palate is slight sugar, much more oak, and very smooth roast and a long finish.  Way to easy to drink for the abv...a good sipper.  Enjoyed at thanksgiving by all who tried.

January 2010 bottling. 750 mL bottle at BeerBistro in Toronto, served in a stem glass. Pours dark chestnut with a small, off-white head that fades to a thin cover and leaves slight lace. On the nose, there are notes of roasted malts with smoke, raisins and oak, along with dark fruit, Belgian yeast, molasses and a hint of slightly sour fruit. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with oak, brown sugar and flowers. The finish is long and malty with oak. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a milky smooth texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice Belgian-style strong ale with raisins, smoke and oaky notes. 2012-01-25

750 ml. Bottled 2006. Deep brown body. Frothy beige head, diminishing. Aroma of oak barrel, dark fruit, vanilla, plum, raisin, cotton candy with hints of molasses and sherry. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Medium body, velvety texture and lively carbonation. Taste of vanilla, wood, candy, cherries. Bread and chocolate notes with a hint peppery alcohol. Nuanced and balanced.

Pours light brown with a whispy head. Aroma is toasted malt and oak with a touch of fig. Taste is oak barrel and medium body malt with a texture on the thinner side. All of the elements work well together. Quite enjoyable.

Botle, shared with Dave at his 40th birthday bash. Deep mahogany pour. Aroma is surprising: much more chocolate than I was anticipating. There are some barrel traits here too, but mostly the soft vanilla tones just add a sweetness to the chocolate, which really seems to dominate. The palate is a little more balanced, but still seems to center around cocoa, with additional notes of sweet dark fruits, oaky wood, and some subtle leather and spices. Very warm finish. This was nice, but wasnt what I thought it would be, and so maybe I was a little underhwelmed.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
The beer appears a deep, dark shade of brown, nearly black. Atop the beer rests an inch of thick beige head that displays lasting retention, leaving a filmy sheet of lacing on the glass.

The aroma is quite complex, offering prunes, charred malt, smoke, oak, roast, figs, dates, nuts, malt, yeast, spice. Certainly an intriguing beer for the olfactory senses.

The flavor brings Belgian characteritics from the onset. Rich malt, yeast, bread, lightly spiced. A robust beer. Mildly sweet, with lingering notes of dark fruits soaked in alcohol. Roasted chestnuts and/or hazelnuts play a strong role as well.

Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. The beer finishes with a pleasant alcoholic warmth.

A fine choice for a nightcap or to sip on a colder winter evening. Too bad its so pricy, else I would purchase it again. For the price, I can get two bottles of St. Bernardus Abt 12 or three bottles of Rochefort 10.

Serving type: bottle

The aroma is good, alot going on. But the flavor was a surpise. There is even more going on in the flavor. Cocoa nibs mixed with vanilla strangled by toasty note. Honey and candy sugar shake hands with your taste buds. Then a nice oak finish comes in and says "Youre Welcome". 10.4abv can not be found. This is recomended.
2010 (feb) bottling.  Strong alcohol in the aroma, nice.  Smooth long taste.  Dark brown.  Barrel-aging far more noticeable on the nose than tongue.  Well made.

Bottle at Monks. Dark orange brown pour with a frothy head due to the bottle conditioning. Some dark barrel aged notes crossed with toasted wheat flavors. Maple syrup. Cocoa powder. Light raisins. Figs. Lighter than most dark aged beers. Medium palate. Gets richer in flavor as it warms. Mixed thoughts on this one because it seems to fall between styles.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2014 From the 6/2012 3R6P tasting +++ Sampled from a 750 ml corked brown bottle this beer poured a dark black color with a small khaki head that left good lacing. The aroma was faint wood and a touch of toasty malts. The flavor was tangy red wine, wood, faint fig, a touch of molasses, table sugar, pepper and cola. The finish was medium length and dry toasty wood and pepper lingering. Medium body. Disappointing.

Pours a beautiful dark mahogany with a thick khaki head. Has great head retention and lacing. Magnificent looking beer. There is an abundance of dark fruits, caramel/molasses and a kind of nuttiness in the aroma. Im also picking up subtle notes of smokey wood from the barrels. The taste is definitely sweeter than the smell. Right up front Im picking up brown sugar, plums, raisins, caramel, and some cocoa. There is a fair amount of oak and vanilla, giving it a nice biscuity finish. Medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Alcohol is too well hidden. Another Allagash Monster!

December 2011 bottling.  Aroma has some burnt sugar character with strong alcohol note, raisins, leather too.  Copper to dark mahogany in color.  Super creamy head that never disappears.  Taste is sweet again with strong alcohol character.  Slightly tannic, not really getting the oak.  Definitely has a sherry character.  Very long finish, warm.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Enjoyable beer.  Would love to taste some straight from the steel tanks so i could appreciate better what the oak adds.

08 Vintage. Brown/black, mahogany edges. Aroma of dark fruit, earthy bitterness, tobacco, some licorice and soy. Taste is nice and mellow, lots of sweetness, some woody bitterness. Very smooth texture, soft carbonation.

(750ml bottle vintage July 2009) clearish medium brown pour with light bubbles. Nose of grape jelly, lightly vinous, sweet Belgian dark candi sugar, bits of cocoa, smells super complex. Taste of concorde grapes, belgian candi sugar, not super spicy. tends more towards the sweet, juicy dark fruits, naturally carbonated, a nice beer!
Bottle shared with friends.  Brown pour with off white head.  Aroma is roasted and woody.  Roast malt, oak, caramel and fruit in flavor.

75cl shared with kermis and friends.
Thin off white head.  Deep ruby pour. Nice enough beer.  Cant taste the barrel aging

Hot damn... 

Dark brown pour. Smokey aroma, with flavor of caramel malt, oak, and general malt deliciousness. oh, and alcohol.

Draft at Mugs Alehouse. Aroma of rich toasted Oak, Toasted Oak on the palate but not too overbearing, Slight Vanilla, caramel and spice,carbonation is lively and makes for a great mouth feel. Well balanced for such a strong beer.

3/6/12. 750mL bottle shared by Larry! Hazy brown pour with a small tan head that fades but laces plenty. Slightly fruity, phenolic aroma with a surprising chocolate and roast kick. Sweet banana flavors with another big chocolate and roast kick, on top of touches of vanilla. Nice!
Bottle pours a clear red/brown with a small, fizzy, off white head. Scent is caramel, wood and booze. Taste is sweet and lightly bitter with wood. Nice

Pour is a mahogany color with a finger thick white head. Nose is of roasted... something. Taste is similar, dominated by the aging notes more than anything, some light vanilla and some strong oak notes.
Nice brown pour with a decent head. The toasted oak is quite pleasant. The alcohol isnt that noticable. Pretty good.
Bread crust, cherries, subtle coffee nose. Clear chestnut, medium yellow head, good lacing. Full bodied, cherry flavor with a touch of whiskey. Not for me, too boozy.

Pours dark chestnut brown in color with a big creamy off white head. The aroma is Belgian yeast under a nice malty but creamy wheat base. The flavor is a solid Belgian Strong Ale malty and yeasty base of flavors with smooth subtle oak notes on a creamy beautiful body.

Bottle at a recent tasting...  [2009 vintage] Poured reddish with a thin, beige head.  Oaky and fruity all over with smooth edge to it.  Dark fruits, quite vinous in character.  Sweet malts, vanilla, oak, wood-like tones, warming heat with more yeast spices and esters.
Typical Belgium, like a desert beer. Complex mouthfeel, gets close to a wine. Long and lasting aftertaste.

On draft at Beer Revolution. It pours ruby red/brown with a small off white head. The aroma has plums, spice, oak and toasted malt. The flavor is dark fruit, bread crust, spice and oak. Very complex, smooth and drinkable. A great Belgian! Top notch. Loved it.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Deep brown with a one finger tan head that lasts to the end... lots of lacing...

S: Oaky, sugar, vanilla, caramel, molasses.. slight smokeyness.

T: Fruits (figs?) lots of caramel/sugar/vanilla malts.. well hidden alcohol.. bourbon like finish.

M: Smooth medium body. Little carbonation.

O Solid american attempt at the beglian strong dark.
dark brown color. Lots of bourbon, dark raisin, dark brown sugars. Lighter body, lots of burnt riasins. Dangerously drinkable
Ruby brown color with tan foam.  dry hay, spicy caramel aromas. medium bodied. Lightly sweet spicy caramel, toffee, herbal flavors--almost good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle shared at STL RB gathering.  Pour is brown with a light tan head.  Aroma is light rye-like malt, faint smoke and a light sweet note.  Flavor is also spicy-sweet rye, faint smokey and roasted malt and a touch of sweet coffee in the finish.  The finish is long nad smooth.  Better than expected.
A strong cinnamon aroma. A dark color with a hint of red and a brown head. A sour taste with a slight bitter taste at the end.   A oily slick feeling. Overall a pleasant clean Ale.

Sampled at the St. Louis RB gathering.  It poured a reddish black color with a small off-white head. The aroma was of vanilla, whiskey, dark fruits and oak. The flavor was of coffee, spices, molasses, and lots of oak. A very good Belgian Strong Ale.

Sampled at the Saint Louis Ratebeer Gathering in a tulip glass, thanks Dan! Poured an attractive dark copper with a little haze, long-lasting white foam and nice lacing. Aroma of wood and woodsy hops, loads of caramel, whole wheat bread, holiday spice cake, few hops but interesting yeast esters. Good bottle-fermentation characteristics. The flavor, sadly, was just a bland strong amber ale. Whats up? Light-medium body, average mouthfeel and finish. Kinda boring result after all the work they put in.

Poured a dark mahogany brown with a short brown head. The head disappeared to just a film very quickly. The aroma was mild and had hints of wine, milk chocolate and molasses. The initial taste of the beer revealed a good amount of effervesence from a good bit of carbonation. There was also a pleasant alcohol flavor that lent a bit of tartness along with the carbonation. Flavors of milk chocolate and caramal malt were light in the middle. The finish had a nice alcohol warmth as the flavors just mellowed away.

Vanilla, wood, and maybe a little licorice in the aroma.  A lot of malt and some smoke in the flavor, with a bit of a bitter finish.  Really good but still slightly disappointing compared to some of Allagashs other efforts.  Ill take the Curieux over this any day.

750ml bottle. Pours dark murky brown with tan head. Aromas of oak, vanilla, raisins, and dark sweet malts. Flavors of vanilla, oak, chocolate, dark fruits, and dark malts. Finish is chalky and sweet. Nice brew.

Bouteille de 750ml avec bouchon de liège. Version 10,3% Janvier 2010. Merci Julien et Pier-Luc. Bière brune avec des reflets rouges. Le nez est agréable avec des notes rôties, du champignon et du caramel. La bouche est vineuse, digeste avec des agréables goûts boisées. Bue en fin de soirée, jai bien aimée son coté digeste.

Bottle at Iceland super tasting. Dark reddish brown pour, off white head, med lacing. Roasty aroma, burnt toast, a bit winey, some off mushroom-like smells. Taste is oaky and boozy, some roasty character, a bit off. Palate is well carbed/heavy bodied. Not their best for sure.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with an average, beige head.  Aroma is mostly roasted malts and alcohol.  Flavor is moderately sweet with notes of caramel, berries and a hint of oak/cask wood.  Slightly bitter at the end.  Overall decent but a little too sweet for my taste.

Bottle. Dark dark brown with ruby notes around the edges in the light. Subtle head that disappeared quickly, but left lacing on the glass. Aroma is malty and has a hint of hops. Maybe a little bit of coffee a la a baltic porter??? Flavor is very malty, but balanced with the oaky richness and some nice bitterness to end. Palate starts creamy and ends with a nice crispness.

Appearance: pours with the appearance of dark old European woods rich in lore. Khaki tannish head. Bottle conditioned so a steady stream of bubbles greets the eyes. Swirls foamy with a khaki collar.

Nose: interesting and intriguing. Chocolate and plum, Hersheys chocolate and ruby port. Smell of the seasons changing to Fall. Grape and plum pomace  stems, skins, and pits. Faint oak planks underneath, almost as an afterthought. Fresh black cherries resting in their own juices with no additives or preservatives. Touch of leather in the back along with more pomace  makes me imagine what the old leather Madera sacks of yore may have smelled like after years of use.

Palate: wow! Subtle and soft, sophisticated and aristocratic. Chocolate and leather, pomace, black cherries both in essence and fresh juice. The pomace lingers in the back of each swallow along with old wine soaked oak. More cherries and chocolate with the addition of red and black grapes. Bakers chocolate teases the top back middle of my tongue. More oak comes out to play as she warms up with campfire and fireplace designs.

Final Thoughts: wow and wow! Allagash Brewing never disappoints and the Odyssey was indeed an odyssey of all the senses. If one is so lucky as to stumble across a bottle or three, embrace greed and buy them all.

Pours a fluffy tan head with a deep brown body.  Aromas of brown sugar, some oak and vanilla.  Flavors of brown sugar, toasted malt, vanilla, anise, dark cocoa,  hint of cherry.  Finish is dry, sticky, slightly bitter, oaky.

750ml bottle (bottled Janauary 2008).  Poured a deep mahogany color with a large whitish fluffy head and lots of rocky lacing.  Smell consisted of big dark fruits, along with some vanilla, honey, and a touch of earth and oak wood in the background.  Taste is smooth and bourbony, with plums and dates mixing with some caramel maltiness. Slight warming alcohol is not overdone and blends into the malts very well. Dark fruits are more pronounced as it warms, with lots of vanilla and woody oak from the barrel aging.  This beer has a very creamy mouthfeel. The beer is full bodied and holds its booze well.  Very easy drinker for its complexity and alcohol.

Tasted 7/8/11. 750ml cork and cage. Thanks to phaleslu for sharing! Pours hazy with a brown hue. Tan head. The alcohol is the most apparent aspect of the olfactory. Followed by graham crackers and fudgy chocolate. Full bodied with a sweet and sticky palate. Decently blended with a noticeable chocolate note. Big and hot!

The oak flavor while not overbearing is what really make this beer special to me. Faint notes hit you on the nose and there is a bit of a woody back taste that really left me looking forward to the next sip. At this point it will have some age on it, but at 10% I think if will have held up just fine and will only grow smoother with age.

2011 bottle @ home, courtesy of gooovikings. Deep brown/black appearance with a lively tan head. Nutty, caramel, toffee, light oak, toasty, brown malty nose. Toasty, toffee, caramel malty, espresso, mildly oaky, lightly charred, hazelnutty flavor. Hazelnut, espresso, toffee aftertaste. Solid.

2006 vintage bottle via and shared with oakbluff. Aromas are of Allbran cereal, yellow raisin, and burnt sugar. Flavours are of salty black licorice, brown sugar, raisin, and oak barrel. Medium bodied. Kinda reminds me of Pannapot, although not quite as good.

On tap at the Stags Head.  Pours a deep brown color with nice beige fluffy head.  tastes of coffee, molasses, figs, plums, dark cherries, and plenty of oak.  Finishes with warming booze malt and smoke.  fantastic.

2006 bottle. Pours Amber and cloudy with a small tan head. Aroma is oak, caramel, little alcohol and has hints of vanilla. Flavor is pretty much the same. Very little oxidation for an 06 bottle. Medium bodied with a malty finish.

750 ml bottle from dbsdelight- thanks a ton, Dan! October 2006 vintage. Pours a cloudy brownish-amber color with a small beige head. Aroma of brown sugar, vanilla, oak, caramel, and sweet fruity bread. The flavor precisely follows suit. Only very minor oxidation has set in and it takes nothing away from the experience. Medium-bodied, with a sweet, coating mouthfeel and low carbonation. Really nice, malty, interesting beer.

Very DArk Brown with nice finger and a half of khaki head. Smell: Roast, Oak, Grape/fig, Alcohol, some graininess/husk. Bits of bready yeast. TASTE vinous/fig, roast, oak/vanilla. more oak, apple skin and a bit of pear. PALATE is dry and slightly tart. OVERALL another roasty american interpretation of belgian ale. not impressed. but not bad either. it was quite palatable.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co. and snifter served with a ruby highlighted, darkest brown color, modest, light tan foam that reduced fairly quickly to a ring & film, but left some clingy, creamy patches & ribbons of lacing. The aroma was a touch of roastiness, dark fruit as plum and prune, and a hint of caskwood. The flavor added to these just a bit of cherry tartness, warming alcohol, and a pleasant, light creaminess to the mouthfeel. An impressively smooth, full bodied Strong Ale!

Pours a deep ebony with light tan head.  Smells like coffe, figs and molasses.  Taste is very balanced brown sugar, pepper and dark fruits (prune?).  Finishes dry with notes of puckering oak, cherries and malty mineral water.  Truly an odyssey for the palate whose stand out quality is a luscious body of thick, curvy adoration that flows like hot oil over my tongue.  This beer actually reminds me a lot of Westvleteren 12.
dark pour with a brownish head. nose is sweet, with a bit of horseblanket and citrus.boozy. nice almsot slight smoke and lots of malt. a bit oakey for my liking but still pretty tasty

(bottle) The body is very dark brown, almost black, and a medium brown head with large bubbles. A strong nose; alcohol is evident, with sweet sugar, and sour acidic notes. Flavor has oak character, and bourbon; roasted malt and a hint of smoke. Some pleasant sourness as well. Underlying bitterness that remains strong in the aftertaste. Strong alcohol presence. Medium body, a touch oily.

Tap at the Moth. Dark reddish maroon color with a ring of beige head. Aroma of dark fruits and brown sugar. Raisins, plums and heavy malts. Flavor is woody and sweet with a slight bitter on the finish. Sweet raisin for sure with a gentle woody burn near the end.
Pitch black pour with a creamy head. Minimal aroma, but taste is a relatively complex, yet balanced. Almost no aftertaste and very smooth drinking.

750ml bottle, January 2010 vintage.  Pours a clear, copper amber with a frothy off white head.  Nose is nice, soft, light yeast, lightly chalky.  Flavor is sweet, prunes, dried fruit, light chocolate, lightly herbal.  Full bodied but very smooth.

750ml bottle from Winooski. br />
Appearance : Clear dark mahogany with a foamy and creamy brown head.

Aroma : Fruits and molasses with light roasted malt. Nice caramel and dark fruits. Some raisins with spicy wood.

Taste : Fruits and molasses with light woody vinous notes. Finish quite woody and tannic. Soft carbonation.

Overall : Very nice stuff. Very nice wood presence. I like the light vinous and tannic notes added by it. Nice surprise.

This strong ale pours a dark brown, you can really tell its brownness in the light, with a light tan head. The head is about a finger but sadly is gone quickly. There is nice lacing but its not very thick or alluring.

The aroma is light but you can say it smells like most strong ales. You get whiffs of hops and a little oak, but Id really like a lot more.

The taste is light and hides the 10% good. There is sweet malty start with a light oak finish.

The feel is viscous and surprisingly drinkable.

On tap @ GLB ....Hazy dark brown pour , big off white head , good lace . Big malt aroma with notes of oak , dark fruit and  roasted malt . Sweet malt flavor upfront , chocolate , fruity , wood  and vanilla . Medium bodied , finish is dry and warming . Excellent

[3613-20110220] 750mL bottle. Lightly spiced grainy malt aroma. Clear, dark red body with a big medium-lasting creamy off-white head. Grainy yeast flavour has a sweet fruity malt throughout. Medium body. Interesting, tasty. (7/3+/8/3/15) 3.6
(w/ GregClow, jerc)

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours dark brown with a small foamy head.  The nose is a bit unique with notes of vanilla, wood, perhaps some anise and caramel.  The flavor picks up bigger notes from the time in the wood (vanilla and oak) but the wheat makes it come across as a little lighter.  Interesting mix.  I am not quite as impressed by this one as everyone else is.

In short: A big sweet dark ale of some kind.  Lots going on here.  Original and good.
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed about 1 year after bottling date
The look: Near black body topped by a light brown ring of foam
In long: Strange nose of black liquorice, pineapples and tar.  Taste has plenty of dark fruits, a lot of toffee, raisins, black liquorice candy, lots of vanilla, barley candy, wheat wine, Belgian yeast sensation, some tobacco leafs. Very little oak presence (if any) for an oak aged beer.  There was some dryness in the finish which can only be explained by the wood.  But not really any oak flavor per say.  Body is full, carbonation is lively but mouthfeel is a bit sticky.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  This is a beer I didnt really care for in the first 1/4th of the bottle but it grew on me and before the end of the bottle I was enjoying it.  This is a good thing because usually big beers do the opposite to me.  Style-wise its a touch one to pigeonhole.  Kind of a big Belgian crossed with a scotch ale.  Overall this is a good beer.  I found this bottle in my beer cellar and I honestly dont even remember buying it.  My beer cellar is like my life.  Plenty of beer and not going anywhere.

2011-02-20. Dark brown body with a  modest foamy tan head. 3+ Modest aroma, lightly tangy fruit character, mild alcohols and sweet malt. 7+ Flavour has a mild malty base with fruity accents and muted woody notes. Fruit character lingers in the finish. Smooth average palate.  Enjoyable but on the mild side. Perhaps it has mellowed with a year in the bottle but this is surprisingly mild for a beer of this strength! Bottled January 2010, via trade with Fred82

(beer tasting @ Montys Krown - Rochester, NY: bottle - corked & caged 750 ml) Cant recall the vintage. Deep reddish color with a thick and fluffy off-white head. Bourbon in the nose along with oak, vanilla and dark fruits. Flavor starts off dark and fruity with a nice oak and vanilla bourbon middle. Finishes slightly tart and with the lightest bitter hint on the aftertaste.

750 ml bottle. 2009 Vintage.   Nose of oak and wheat. Thin head that produced great lacing that stayed until the end. Taste is a oak wood upfront (Cedar taste, if you could eat wood) Has a wheat base. Finish is a light toffee or vanilla ester in the mixture of complex ingredients.  A fine aged brew that was balanced perfectly.
Co-rate!  Tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad barrel event. Brown color. Aroma of Hershey bar and earth. Taste is dirty caramel. Next to Avance, this was tame.
Tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad barrel event.  Brown color.  Aroma of Hershey bar and earth.  Taste is dirty caramel.  Dull.
Clear mahogany, off white head. Aroma is loaded with bourbon, tannic vinous character. Flavor again bourbon, warming alcohol, vanilla, warming alcohol. Oily smooth mouthfeel.

Sampled at the Brewvival 1.  Near clear brown pour with no head.  Sweet caramel, and a little burnt, scotch and nuttiness.  Kinda boring actually. Or maybe my palate had already been blown out. I dont know what it was particularly, but I didnt really care for this one too much.

Sampled from a bottle at Mondial de la bière.  Dark hazy copper with a film of beige head.  There is the scent of orange in the nose, along with a little spice.  And maybe a vegetal note, although that may just be my nose malfunctioning.  In the flavour there is lotsa yeast, sweet vanilla/oak, and spice at the end.  Medium-full body, medium-low carbonation.  Pretty good, overall.

750 ml corked asnd caged bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of toffee, spice, oak, stale popcorn and dark fruit. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of oak, vanilla, toffee, carmel, stale popcorn and dark fruit with a crisp lingering toffee finish.

Big thanks to overlord for this bottle. July 2009 bottling.

A: Pours a dark brown that is ever-so-slightly transparent when held to the light. Thin tan head that dissipates with a little lacing in its wake.

S: A good amount of dark fruits. Not super pungent, but the only thing that really stands out. A bit of caramel and toffee in the background.

T: The dark fruits distinguish themselves a bit more alongside caramel, toffee, and some yeasty spices. Not picking up oak here or in the nose.

M: Fairly creamy. Medium body and good carbonation.

D: Better as it warms up past cellar temperature, but nothing terribly special at this point. Its lacking in any real depth, which is surprising given that the bottle is nearly a year old.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-25-2010

1 Pint 9.4oz bottle. Bottling: January 2010 - opened: 10/30/2010. Poured a dark, almost murky brown with ruby edges - thick beige head. Aroma: fruit, chocolate, cotton candy, roasted malts, oak background with some faint booze. Taste was like the aroma: full body loaded with flavor and very balanced. Long finish of roasted malt and sweet chocolate. Very carbonated. Overall a fantastic beer.

6oz glass from a flight.  Pour is deep amber with a small amount of off-white head.  Nose is currants, raspberries, wheat, and light molasses.  Taste is right on par with a lovely triscuit that rolls into the finish to make an excellent brew.  This is a fantastic brew and doesnt come off nearly as acidic as many high ABV wheat s Ive had.  Though I havent loved Allagash brews in the past, this is definitely on their best!

0.65 l bottle at Monks Porterhouse, Stockholm. Dark brown color. Thick aroma of raisins, coffee, prunes and licorice. The flavors of raisis, prunes, coffee, oak and vanilla. Nice dark fruit character but this is too oaky for my liking.

Bottled July 2009, 10.4% ABV.
Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip.

A: Pours a jet black with ruby red peeking out of the corners and a one finger light beige head.
S: A bit of Belgian funk, dark fruits, and heavy oak on the finish. 
T: Big sweet malt with brown sugar in the beginning with nice vanilla, oak, and toffee to follow.
M: Perfect level of carbonation, and lighter bodied than similar high ABV brews, with the wheat base as opposed to a traditional stout base.
D: Wow, brilliant, this tastes like an imperial stout with Belgian funk in the nose but not enough to influence the taste all that much (unlike Belgian style imperial stouts like JP Dark Dawn). The wheat base helps this beers cause as it makes it lighter and easier to drink.
Dark but not cloudy, with thin head. Faint but sweet/smoky aroma. Chocolate and wood. An odd dustiness. Dry. Not too sure about this one. Elements of stout and Belgian.

Pours near black with an appreciable tan head. Very pleasant aroma with light fruity yeast and clearly present malts. Danky flavor of yeast and dark malts and fruit. Light lacing. Slight coffee aftertaste.
Jan 2008 bottle. Robust sweet malt fruit aroma. Amber color with a small tan head. Light sweet beginning. Sweet fades while a mild alcohol burn develops in the finish. light palate.

A firm, off-white head form easily over this deep, dark brown brew. Vibrant ruby highlights at the edges. Malt and yeast come to the nose bringing yeast and raisins and other dark dried fruits. As it warms, the character takes on more smooth light molasses notes. Sweet, bittered by dark roast malts.

750ml bottle, 2009 vintage, 600 cases bottled.  Oak aged ale poured a dark amber brown with slight tan head.  The aged feel is blended with fruity wheat beach-wood notes.  Some dry sweet bitterness in the finish.

750ml bottle from Sloth in a trade. Poured in a snifter, a dark concoction with ruby edges and a thick and diminishing head.  Fruity aroma and very Belgian like with notes of yeast and spices. Peppery as well. Body is super smooth and somewhat luscious and full. The oak comes late in the finish with malty sugary flavors. A solid ale from Allagash! Thanks Bert!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: On tap at rattle n hum.  Not too heavy, a brown ale type feel.  Some chocolate decent.  Allagash is overrated.

The darkest chocolate brown with beige drifts and lace.  Irish coffee, rich and boozy on the nose with dried fruit and damp earth.  Smooth as anything in the mouth, rich and not too boozy at all but a pleasing warmth is generated.  Surprisingly sweet with a dense Marmite finish.

A great compliment for the cigars we were having that night. The taste was very smooth and oaky, with a dried fruit quality. The aroma was big and robust with hints of dried fuit and a slight hint of oak. Not much more to say because Im pretty wasted , but pick this one up now!!!!

Draft at the Three Penny Taproom - Poured a dark brown in color with a small tan head that settled to produce some minor lacing on the glass.  Aroma is woody with caramel and some bready Belgian yeast.  Flavor is pretty much the same with a bit more of the roastiness of the oak and some dark fruit.  I thought that this was a good one...

Pretty good brew. Poured with a small to medium light tan head that mostly settles out and a bit of lace. Color is a lovely, clear mahoganey. Aroma is really nice with some slightly smokey, roasty malt, burnt wood, dark ripe fruit and a bit of toffee. Flavor is like that, but lots of the smoke disappears leaving only a bare hint; sweetness comes out more but all is well balanced. Body is just right, mouth filling and cut well by carboantion. Finish is like flavor, fairly long and with an oakey lingering sweetness along with some alcohol. Again a tad sweet for me to drink more than this botte. But it is a pretty pow beer.

Bottle shared by levifunk - Dark and murky brown with a light brown head. Leather and tobacco on the nose, with lots of dark malt. Lots of lightly smoked malt with vinous notes, tobacco, dark fruit--lots going on here. Smooth in the mouth and lightly carbonated, this feels pretty good in the mouth. Really nice.
Pours reddish brown with white head. Nose is alcohol, Belgian yeast and fermenting dark fruits. Taste is aged cherry, oak, little booze and Belgian yeasts.

Bottle Pours out a dark brown with some red highlights topped with a sandy head. Aroma was of sweet malts, caramel, wood, and some bread. Taste was much as the aroma with a good about of the barrel showing threw. Plenty of the sweetness and spice to help push the wood back.

On tap at Downtown Johnny Browns into tulip. Pours a dark brown almost black with small tan head. Aroma of toasted malts and lots of wood character. Mouthfeel is thick with moderate carbonation. Taste is very similar in aroma, very roasty flavors and hints of dark fruits and wood. Excellent brew.

Appearance: Pours a cola brown with a thin ring of head.

Aroma: Super faint banana, really not much nose on this pour.

Taste: Sweet, spicy roasty wheat, banana, slight earthy wood note finishing with some hop spice.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied modest carbonation.

Overall:  The beer is balanced, but really underwhelming for such a fancy expensive beer. There are plenty of other Allagash beers I would pluck off the shelf before this one.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 Wow, this blew me away!  Brown with tan head- filtered (-1 on appearance).  Aroma and flavor reveal a nice toasted woodiness, probably from the aging process.  This couples with a beautiful combination of toast, roast, and bread crust, as well as darker fruit flavors (dates, raisins).   Incredibly tasty.  Complex and intense yet drinkable to the highest degree!

UPDATED: APR 22, 2011 Brown mahogany pour light tan head ....decent lacing .... sweet malty aroma ... taste of sweet caramel and roasted malt, chocolate and oaky very smooth dark fruits .... mellow and absolutely no trace of the abv ..... very sessionable and enjoyable brew

A Mes rate. Bottle at Marios.Deep dark mahogany with a good beige head. Cheesy and funky aroma with some faint alcohol and fruit. Pleasant but not assertive. Very barrelly in the mouth but not overdone at all. Hints of pineapple and alcohol, good caramel and chocolate (although very subtle) and a big wooden finish. I like this you know. Surprisingly easy drinking for a 10.4% beer. Id quite happily get messy on this. Good stuff.

Draft at Stone the Monday after Oakquinox. Pours murky brown with a big, creamy, offwhite head and sheet lace. Smells sweet and caramelly and fruity malty, some sugar and cardboard. Tastes about the same. Sweetness, kind of weird. Just a hint of wood, used and abused wood. Medium body, nice smooth carbonation.

City Beer Store, Allagash night.  Very dark ruby/brown beer with a great big head, beige with lots of lacing.  I always have a hard time describing Allagashs beers; theres some subtlety thats difficult to put into words.  The beer builds on a clean grain flavor with big caramel/brown sugar and fruity malt notes, raisins and plums.  Theres some definite dark malt presence, as well.  Chocolate and light coffee add some very interesting touches.  Lots of oak and definite bourbon (better than Curieux but still a tad odd, in my opinion).  Carbonation is relatively light.  Flavor is fairly sweet.  It doesnt quite come together for me, but its an interesting and obviously well-made beer.

06 Draft @ NotB 10. Black pour with no head. Sweet notes including caramel, cookie like malt flavors, some light funky characteristics, dark fruit, and some light oak. Nice but a little expensive for the bottle.
Pours dark brown, thin tan head that vanishes too quickly. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, cherry, oak.  Excellent flavor. Quality through and through.

Draft served at Jake Melnicks in Downtown Chicago, served in a snifter type glass. Dark Brown and opaque with a nice thick head. Lots of oak and maltiness in the aroma. Like the aroma, picking up oak and woody bark flavors in the taste with a little dry cocoa and dark fruit flavors.
Good carbonation and medium bodied -- not as heavy as the dark color might indicate. No signs of the 10% ABV, very smooth going down. As the bartender joked, "This is so smooth, Id give to my mom". Would pair well with sharp cheese or a hearty stew.

Bottled July 09. Poured into my Duvel tulip glass.

A-Body is a nearly opaque dark brown-cola color. Pours with a 2-3 finger foamy off-white head that fades quickly to a thin collar. Leaves minimal lacing behind in the glass. Bubbles can be seen steadily rising to the top.

S-Impressions of anise, cola, and root beer come through initially with a slight spicy yeast overtone. Phenols can be detected at a moderate strength.

T-Much like the nose the overall impression this brew gives off initially is that of root beer, anise, and cola. A wet oak presence is minimal in the background. After a few sips a spicy belgian yeast comes through and blends well with the initial flavors. The finish is spicy and sweet with the slightest hints of molasses and oak coming through as well as a moderate alcohol warmth.

P-Medium to high tingly carbonation and a light to medium weight body. Body is wet and yeasty but there is a slight phenolic consistency as well.

O- This is a great beer overall. ABV still somewhat detectable but not out of check in any way, shape or form. I wish there was a bit more oak barrel presence as well. Overall I think this is a great brew and great example of BSDA and measures well against the greats of the style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-19-2010 03:34:17

Bottled feb 2005, bottle from Dickinsonbeer, thanks! Dark brown color. Porto, sherry notes, raisin and dsut in the aroma. Oak and vanilla. Oaky flavor with vanilla and raisin, milk chocolate, porto notes, hazelnuts and some warming alcohol. Amazing omplexity. Toffee notes in the long aftertaste. Characterful and lovely brew.
Mahogany in color; yeasty and fruity, but relatively light in flavor. Alcohol is masked well, this beer can really sneak up on you.

Draught at Teresas. Smelled smooth and oaky, almost mistook it for an imperial stout but theres no doubt it has underlying complexities; fruity phenols emphasized by the belgian yeast, malty, bready, raisin, and some licorice. The flavor is similarly complex with a woody oaken edge that balances out the sweet caramel and subtle fruit and vanillin notes that come through. Its body is copiously endowed and seductively smooth for such a rich beer. Definitely a beer I want again.

Sampled at a tasting at Pacific Park Market, Thanks Ken!

Dark brown, toasty, very nice.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2010 Smooooth! Wow, great drinking smokey oak-aged ale. I definitely get a bit of "Belgian" flavor, superb mouthfeel, and very nice hint of alcohol. I had expected a sharper alcohol taste, but am pleasantly surprised at this obviously well-crafted Allagash offering.

Caramel nose, a bit of alcohol and oak. Flavor is chocolate, molasses, wood, and alcohol.  Medium body but not heavy, soft carbonation, and dark brown with light brown medium head. Did I mention Smooth? Tasted from the bottle @ 60°F.

Second taste: 2010

Aroma is malty & wood. Light brown head, fluffy and BIG! SLightly reddish brown and a heavier pour than the 2009. Superb mouthfeel. Smooth, well balanced and hard to describe. Wood, malty, mushroom, brown sugar, and oddly dry on the finish. Alcohol is more subtle than 2009 and certainly than what I would expect in a 10%+ beer.
On tap at Stone Bistro.  Dark red/brown pour.  Sweet malt, bread, caramel, dark fruit, raisin and hints of wood.  Pretty good beer, enjoyable, but not spectacular.
had at st. stephens. pours a dark body with nice lacing. aroma is bready and sweet. flavor is thick with raisins and sweet malts. great brew.

A bomber from the wooden keg in celebration of the birth of Samuel.  A nice balance between strong alcohol and malt.  aromas are:  bread, caramel, roasty, alcohol, raisin, raisin, woody, Appearance is: brown, hazy with a minimal head, white foam, Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, average carbonation.  would try again.

Bottle from Lone Hill Liquor.  Pours a very dark burgundy color with a short, creamy beige head.  Aroma is initially chocolate and oaky vanilla, opening up to dates and figs with some phenolic notes and lots of lingering dried fruits.  Flavor is again initially chocolate with a subtle roastiness, then some oak and dried fruits, and a sherry like finish that is a touch dry.  Palate is soft and creamy, full bodied but not overly so.  This beer manages to be bold and yet very balanced at the same time, good stuff.

Draft sample @ Brewvival on 2/27/10.  Solid beer from Allagash... really nice American Oak presence over the nose... dark pour with an average head... dark fruits and sweet malts really dominate the body... Belgian yeast finish.

Drank at a local gathering in GSO (on tap). Stong aroma, hints of red grapes, plums, bready malts, with a hint of oak.  Rich dark black, almost a very dark purple color.  Litlle to no head,  and a sort of sparkling color. Tastes of plum, grapes, bready, a little chocolate...all with no taste of alcohol. A very good beer, tought to drin a lot of them at 10.4%, but regardless a goodie.
Pouring at EBFs Night of the Barrels.  Pours a hazy ruby with a thin tan head.  Mustard, caramel, cookies.  Sweet caramel and toffee along with some light toast.
Beautiful nose and pretty to look at. My only gripe would be a rather thin palate. Alcohol is very well hidden.

750ml, corked & caged bottle, July, 2009 batch from Greens in Columbia. pours a very dark brown, almost black, with hints of purple in the light and a soft, bubbly, khaki head with great lacing. aroma is excellent with tart fruit notes of currant, red grape, and plum balanced by sweet chocolate, bready malts, roasted almonds, and a hint of oak. flavor is wonderful with sweet, doughy malts, chocolate, and toffee blending with dried fruit notes of fig, prune, and raisin with hints of tart, red grape, dry cedar, and belgian spices. a very subtle touch of oak, vanilla, and whiskey come through on the finish. palate is medium bodied and highly carbonated yet creamy at the same time. overall, a great brew.

4 oz. sampler at Sunset. Its hard for me to give this beer a fair rating. You can tell its a high quality brew, but it just tasted too much like cough drops for me to enjoy. Otherwise, iit was a good strong wheat ale..

75 cL bottle, 2008 oak aged. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is dark breadish and roasted malty. Slight phenolic. Smooth chocolate and breadish flavoured. Mild vanilla note. Light toffeeish flavoured into a medium dry finish.

Favres a beast .. . Pours a purple black, sturdy creamy medium head .. . well, i hope your kids look like monkeys .. . slick .. simple but delicious, an underlining brilliance .. . tar, grape, plum, rum, and light fruit squares .. . good .. . you say shit alot..

January 2008 bottling, poured into a tulip.

Pours dark, dark brown with hints of copper showing when held up to light.  There is a small creamy tan head that recedes to a small collar and swirl in the middle.

The aroma is sweet with dark chocolate, molasses and dark fruit - raisins, plums and even some grapes.  There is also a noticeable dark roasted malt character and some wood and bourbon.

The taste is spectacular and unbelievably complex.  There is a base of roasted chocolate malts with molasses and dark fruits mixed in.  The finish is chocolaty but with a definite bourbon and oak presence.  The flavors just keep coming as it warms - figs, raisins, rum, tobacco, licorice, you name it.

The mouthfeel is very, very smooth, full bodied with good carbonation.  Dessert-like overall.

I had this beer about a year ago and remembered it being good, but, wow, this is an excellent beer, probably my favorite from Allagash.  It has so many things going on but they all seem to merge together perfectly.  Superb beer.

Pours dark brown to black with a cream-colored head. The aroma is awesome with Belgian yeast, malt and some chocolate. The flavor is roasted malt, yeast, oak and some chocolate and alcohol. I may also get some vanilla, but it is faint if it is there. Medium-thick, creamy mouthfeel with low carbonation. A great beer.

Bomber from the local for a co-worker beer tasting. Pours a reddish black with a small off white head. Aroma was vanilla, whiskey, dark fruits, and oak. The flavor was kind of complex and hard for me to pin down. Coffee, spice, molasses, and oak stuck out the most. This was quite different from anything Ive had but ultimately I thought it was a bit watery.
750->tulip: Pours a thin, offwhite head that exhibits good lacing atop a black body.  Oaky, sweet aroma.  Full bodied, sweet taste, sticky mouthfeel, ending milky.  A very satisfying brew.
Spicy, zesty and complex.  Intriguing, but watery and ultimately too hard to enjoy.  On tap at the Flying Saucer in San Antonio.

08 and 09 back to back.
08-pours black with no real head. aroma is rich and malty with some sweetness and chocolate. drinks really smooth with chocolate and malt sweetness but oak isnt really noticable. smooth and sweet chocolate on the finish. alcohol is still present.
09-pours black with little off white head. aroma is the same as 08 but no quite as strong at this point. flavors are the same but a little more muddled and doesnt seem really put together. higher carbination and a little more caramel present. better with age.

Pours a deep brown with a ring of thick tan head. Aroma of malt, currants, caramel, and fig. Lovely flavor of rich chocolate, currants, plum, vanilla bean, and oak. The mouthfeel is excellent: not thick by any means but full and slightly sticky. Very solid.

750ml bottled on July 2009. Pours a dark brown with 1 finger head and some sticky lace.  Smell is of malt and caramel.  Taste is malt, caramel, dark fruit.  Average carbonation and nice alcohol warmth at the end.  Very much worth the price.

Bottle from Olive Tree Market.  Pours a deep amber with a slight ruby hue, frothy beige head with some spotty lacing.  Some candie sugar, coffee grounds, cocoa dust and dried dark fruits on the nose.   Very woody on the palate with hints of charred oak, spice, yeast and dried figs......tasty stuff.

Tap at Barcade: Deep brown with an amber hue and an off white ring of head. The aroma is richly malty- raisiny with some brown sugar, toasted fig, and mild oak. Silky on the palate. Drier flavor than expected from aroma. Mild raisin notes with a toasted dark fruit not of fig and date with a lot of toasted dry oak on the back. Tannic and interesting.
Thanks after4ever!  January 2008 bottle.  I love toasty oak.  Yum.  Oranges too.  Very dark toffee.  Medium toast, gentle wood.

Bomber shared at the first official Work Beer Club meeting.  Pours a deep brown with thick dense head.  Vanilla nose / nuts and oak too.  Medium malt dominated body.  No heat noticable.  10.5%?  YMBM!!!  Body is surprisingly light.   Them thar Maniacs can sure make some decent suds.

750ml corked and caged from Tom.  Dark brown, almost black with classic allagash carbonation.  Mild toasty, marzipan, cherry, oak, Italian plum sweetness.  Less sweet and as carbonated as most Allagash brews, and I am enjoying that.  The wheat is also working for me to add that little bit of chewiness.  But, just like other Allagash beers it is really well made.
I thought this was a good beer but it it misses somehow.  It needs to be sharper.  It is a little on the bland side with a woody taste and a good amount of roasted malt.
Draught. Poured dark with almost no head. Flavors were mild bit of dark fruits and wood, consistency was  a bit watery.  COuld have used a bit more bite IMO.
2008 bottle.  Very drinkable.  Slight head, very dark body.  Extremely smooth for the alcohol content.

On tap at Pizzeria Paradiso. Pours pretty much jet black with a thin but super thick buttery light yellow head that has unreal retention and leaves just cascades of unbroken lacing. Destroyed the glass. Aroma is a bit muted (since it was served too cold. Theres some coconut, currants, chocolate truffles. Taste is unreal: just a beautiful, rich blend of rum raisin, malaga gelato, flaked coconut, and pina colado. Wow. Great, creamy palate. 10% is unnoticed.

Dark brown, almost black pour with a vivacious, lasting tight frothy tan head that leaves a nice dark coating of lacing in its wake. Aroma is dominated by the quindessential allagash yeast character, and all the yummy spices it tends to produce. Oak, currant, fig, clove, banana, and a citrusy wheat malt combine with the ever prevalent doughty yeast character to produce an excellent arangement of notes. Flavor is absoluely bursting- sweet succulent dark fruit- fig, grape, black currant, and molasses are met with a definitive woody toast note that subsides into an ever so slight hint of roast and a boozy vinousness. Palate is caressing, thick, and excellently effervescent.

Extremely dark brown pour, solidly sized light tan head that retains nicely; visible carbonation in the liquid. Aroma is full of dark spices like clove, along with some classic Allagash Belgian yeast. This is complemented by the second tier of smell, which holds some nice wheat, wood, and toast. Flavor is excellent; lots of wood and toast again, but there is some beautiful dark sugar that comes through; caramel, candied apple, and molasses. The spice comes through once again later on, with delicious dark Belgian notes and a touch of brandy. Palate is really nice; certainly full bodied, but relaxes itself into a sweet but clean and unfettered finish. One of my favorites from Allagash, and an exquisite Belgian strong.

Cask (gravity) @ GBBF 09, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England.Clear dark brown color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, berry, cask wood - oak, smoke, alcohol. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20090806]
Brown with a small off-white head. Dark dried fruit and malt in the nose. Sweet and malty flavour with toffee notes. Alcohol noticed. Too boring for a 10% beer.

From bottle. Mature fruit, malt and liquor aroma. Similar to a proper west country cider. Mahogany in colour with a thin white lace. Slightly smoked flavour with fruit and berries. Smooth texture. Rich flavour, very fruity with caramel. Pleasant tasting beer with a rich finish. Good desert beer.

On tap at th Bistro Barrel Aged fest in Hayward.  Dark brown with purple hues and a small beige head.  Arom is dark fruit, caramel, alcohol, and spices.  Flavor is nice but not quite worth the bottle price.  Caramel malt, spice, raisin, fig, and vanilla.  Alcohol well-hidden.  Dry finish with medium body and a pretty average mouthfeel.
20th June 2008. Smooth but dry. Wood flavours dominate but also seems to impart extra dryness. Very drinkable but not quite joined up enough to be great.

Cask Stillage at the GBBF, Earls Court 06/08/2009
Fruity slight roast aroma. Dark coloured very strong in alcohol and fruity with a little bitterness in a crisp and warming malt finish.

750 ml. bottle from Greens on Ponce De Leon. Black in color. Looks like an imperial stout! Aroma is rather odd. A little nut or toast in the aroma?! Strong malt presence with some burnt wood. The nut is starting to go away and I am picking up a rather strong fruit/sweet candy aroma. Slightly nuanced, but the aroma just isnt that impressive. Flavor is a bit weak as well. WTF? Hmmm...98 I dont know about that. Malt and fruit flavor. The wood is playing such a small role, I wouldnt have guessed that this was wood-aged at all. Alcohol is noticeable in the flavor. Just a rather weak Belgian Strong, not making any type of statement. A rather boring beer. I dont even think Homer would have enjoyed this Odyssey.

FOBAB 2009-  pours a dark brown with  a small beige head.  notes of dirt, must, cobwebs, bread.  not too great.  some plastic and feces notes as well.  underwealming.  Booze was well hidden though, didnt seem like 10.4% abv.
draft: pours black, malty, oak aroma, malt and vanilla taste with a fairly fully mouthfeel

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2009 Tap at Blind tiger. Poured a medium brown with a thin white head.  Nice malts and candied sugars make this a very tasty Belgian strong. Maybe a less sweet and thinner version of rochefort 8, but almost as delicious, almost. Nice depth of flavor which keeps this brewer at the top of American Belgian style ales.

08 bottle. Found this quite different from the tap version I had a few weeks ago. Nose was much more oaky. This was much more carbonated also. Similar rich flavors but much more of the wooden and slightly smoked flavors. Similar depth of flavors but not as sweet as the younger version. I liked them both but prefer the aged version.

Reviewed 8/19/2009 (Bottled January 2008):

Pours a very dark brown colored body, with a big creamy tannish color head.  Lasting.  Fruity aroma, some dark fruit, and some lightish fruit too.  Some fig, and some alcohol too.  Some roasted notes, and maybe some chocolate.  Very strong aroma, kind of funky. Roasty, woody taste.  Some wood taste, probably the oak barrel.  Some smoke too. This could age in taste very well. Very carbonated. Not sure I really like the taste.  A little harsh now, maybe in a few months or years it would taste better.

Pours a very dark chestnut brown color with a huge frothy, pillowy tan head with excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that leaves chunks of soapy lacing in its wake.

Chocolate malty aroma that is slightly earthy with hints of oaky wood. Dark fruit notes and peppery spice also present.

Creamy malty body with lots of estery dark fruit notes, especially raisin, prune, plum, and dark berries with lots of peppery zest, chocolate malts and earthy oak. Very smooth and quaffable with hints of grape and cherry dark fruit. Very nice balance of dark fruit and chocolate malt. The ABV is excellently balanced without a trace of alcohol warmth making this beer extremely quaffable. Sweet dry finish. Excellent!

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with Braden. Pours deep amber, with a thick, lasting beige head. Aroma of figs, raisins, roasted malts, and hints of chocolate, soil, and chesnuts. Full bodied with a heavy, creamy mouthfeel. Excellent Belgian strong. Highly recommended.

On tap at OBriens Pub in San Diego. A beginner of a fine evening of weeknight drinking late in September with Katie. Color is dark brown with a fine developing white lace served in a Chimay chalice. Aroma is mostly ashy smoke and dark fruit, with raisins and cherry tossed in the mix. Flavor is fairly light and dry, with bitter smoke and just a hint of oak showing through in the finish. Dark fruits comprise most of the flavor up front. Belgian yeast notes linger in the finish. Pretty tasty.

2006 Bottle - Thanks Ughsmash! - Pours a thin black with a medium beige head...aroma is vanilla oak, caramel and cocoa...flavour is similar, toast, massive wood and sweet creme, chocolate malt and more sweet wood...plenty of unfermented sugars in this, but not sticky, just sweet...the oak is #1 and everything else is secondary in this brew, and I really dug it...

Dark brown almost still pour.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, oaky tannins, and chocolate on the nose.  Flavor does not live up to the aroma.  Flavor is Earthy with notes of toffee, chocolate, vanilla, light bourbon, & toasted hazelnut.

Dark fLat pour barley no head. Aroma of sweet dark caramel choc brown sugars hints of vanilla and a hint of bourban boozy nose. Almost a slight bitter choc in the flavor lots of the oaky bourban comes through And even some darkfruit lot more fizz at the front then expected. Very easy drinking and very yummy!

Dark brown pour with no head. Aroma is  brown sugar, vanilla oak, slightly vinous.  Flavor is oakey with some vanilla notes and dark fruit, dates ands some dark sugar.  The finish is sublime. New flacors of codes and roasty choclate come though. Complex brew. really fantastic

Deep garnet body colour with a shinning surface. Smell of sweet, dark berries with vanilla hints. Spicy and sweet taste of  berries and dark fruits from start to finish. Some vanilla hints from the oak barrel. Well integrated alcohol. A tasty drink, full bodied (One-third pint, gravicask, USA bar, GBBF 06.08.2009).

Thanks to DrinknDrive for this trade bottle.  Pours dark brown with an off-white head.  Nose is nuts, earth, spice, toasted malt, slight vinegar, bitterness, and booze.  Flavor is same with some maple, nuts, toasted malt, slight vinegar, booze, and bitterness.  Medium-bodied, and ok overall.  Disappointing for what the label promised.

Bottle courtesy of markwise. Pours a hazy dark cola brown with reddish highlights and a thin tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of oak, smoke, caramel, light chocolate, grain, anise, brown sugar. Flavor is sweet and malty with earthy notes, caramel, brown sugar, earthy goodness, wood, smoke, anise, light honey and spice notes. Generally medium body with malty sweet finish.

Real solid for sure.  Smells of mesquite barbeque smoke, soy sauce and vanilla extract.  Coca cola brown with garnet hues and a thin tan head to be delicately slurped.  Flavor is rich, woody, earthy minerals and burnt sugar cookie with an alcoholic tacky finish.  Interesting brew all around and very satisfying with grilled food for sure.  Thanks Allagash.  2008 22 oz. from our boy Scott at Oak Tree Buy Rite.

Dark nut brown color, small beige head. Licorice and tar in the nose as well as dark malts. Flavor has sweet caramel, some wood, licorice, vanilla and calvados. Liquerish palate. Some roasted notes in the aftertaste with sweetness.
